user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
Slightly orange, slightly lemon, slightly Norwegian Spruce. Sweet and bitter with a zesty character. 
Light amber with a slight haze (thanks non-filtration). Ample head which stays for ages slightly masking the nose.
Sweet and sharp with a bitter finish, not unlike a pink grapefruit - pith included.
This beer balances very nicely on the palate with medium weight, and smooth, slightly creamy texture. Persistent bubbles make for a lively mouthful. The finish is swamped in citrus and sweet malt, with a bitterness which lingers, reminding me again of the grapefruit pith.
Overall this is an awesome beer. 16 oz cans make this an even better experience. Don;t be put off by the fishy packaging.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
There is a little funk on the nose which interrupts the orange malt.
Color is crisp clear orange with an off white head which held for a while.
Bitterness is very mild, swamped by the chewy malt and a strange savory character which floats around in the background.
The body is medium to full, and somewhat chunky. Texture is thick and creamy. Plenty of bubbles but the finish is short and boring.
Overall this is not a beer which did much for my palate and I probably wont drink the second half of this 22oz bottle.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
Bold orange citrus nose with more than its share of bright hoppy character. A whiff of sweet maltiness hits you a moment after you adjust to the sharpness.
Dark orange in color with a shade or two of brown creeping in. Head is white and fell apart quickly but left some lacing on the side of the glass.
Bitter and sweet are both big components, but also balance each other very well. The bitterness wins out with its length.
The body is bold and fairly full leading to a slightly thicker than expected texture. Very lively bubbles keep pushing flavor into the mouth, Sweet and bitter finish, but the orangey maltiness fades before the sharp bitterness does.
I like this beer a lot because it is well balanced, even though the balance is further down to the bitter end of the scale, the maltiness is bold enough to stand up to it.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
The nose is bright with bitter citrus and touch of sweet floral for great balance.
This beer is a misty golden color with a frothy white head.
Medium bitterness hit the tongue first with the sweetness which was promised on the nose just sneaks in.
The mouth-feel is light and crisp with plenty of bubbles. The finish is quick and slightly flat, contrasting the delights that the aroma suggested.
Overall this beer disappointed. Having enjoyed other offerings from Stone this one fell short of the mark. To be fair, it is brewed to be a sessionable IPA so removing the alcohol has taken away somewhat from the body. Compared to other session IPAs its a winner.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
The nose is a little flat, but a little bitter orange crept in with a yeasty malt sweetness.
The color is a bright orangey amber with a big off white head. Lively carbonation and a nice clarity.
Mostly mild bitterness with a touch of sweetness at the finish define the taste.
The body is bold without being big. Texture is creamy with a touch of stickiness, but the beer flows well. A lively bubble lasted to the bottom of the glass. The finish is in 2 stages, the boldness and sweetness tail off quickly making you think its done, but a bitter encore makes a pleasant surprise.
Overall, this is one of my go-to IPA as it delivers a consistent and bold style. I would recommend it to anyone to use as a benchmark for tasting other IPA.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
The nose gives huge amounts of orangey malt with a touch of grapefruit.
The color is light amber and hazy with bubbles and nummies aka sediment.
Medium sweetness leads while the stealthy bitterness attacks like a grapefruit pith ninja in the mid palate,
The body is deceptively full. The ascorbic character disguises the boozy weight of this ale until you have had a few mouthfuls. Plenty of bubbles keep the sediment moving around the glass. The finish is medium length and kind of clean.
Overall this is a great beer, if not a little pricey. Its limited release window and distribution radius make it a much sought after beer. Definitely worth a try if you can get your hands on one.

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
Aroma is loaded with bitter green hops, dandelion and thistle with a warm malty backdrop.
The appearance is a hazy amber liquid with a fast fading white head which leaves fractional lacing.
The taste is big all around. Tons of bitterness easily covers a solid sweet malty wall.
This beer fills the mouth, attacking every corner of the palate. The body is full with a boozy syrupy texture which is totally forgivable thanks to the big bitter finish. Carbonation remained lively through the end of the glass.
Overall this is an awesome beer. Awesome in flavor, awesome in body, awesome in alcohol. Buy some

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
Nutty sweet nose with orange citrus bouncing around with a tinge of tropical fruit.
Excellent clarity, bright orange color, clean white head which leaves a good lacing on the side of the glass.
This beer has everything, sweet, gentle bitterness with a slightly salty touch. The bitterness lingers on the finish.
The body is light for an Imperial IPA , and the texture is clean and easy drinking, with slight carbonation. The finish is lengthy and complex with sweet orange, bitterness and another touch of nuttiness.
I would recommend this to any IPA fan, if they can find it. This is quickly becoming my favorite beer of the year so far. Buy one NOW!

user_location: of Cellars Wines and Spirits Inc Minnesota
review_blob:
Masses of pine resin and citrus almost completely cover the big malt nose.
The bright golden amber color belies the big bold flavors. The head is white and fairly thin.
Sweet maltiness and strong bitterness dominate the taste buds.
The body starts with a medium feel but fills the mouth quickly with a creamy character. The sharp grapefruit catches up quickly and then dominates. The malt lingers after the citrus fades leaving a bitter sweet finish which holds just long enough.
This is the 2014 release of Ruin Ten and is just as good as I remember in 12 and 13. This beer will score well with the hopheads and the Stone fanboys and quite rightly. Awesome IPA
